description: From Middle English defamen, from Anglo-Norman defamer (verb), defame (noun), and its source, Latin diffāmō, from fāma (“fame; rumour; reputation”).

examples: And all the sparks that may bring unto flame / Hate betwixt man and wife, or breed defame.

entries.meaning: (now rare or nonstandard) Defamation; slander, libel. [from 15th c.]

verbs.description: defame (third-person singular simple present defames, present participle defaming, simple past and past participle defamed)

entries.meaning: To disgrace; to bring into disrepute. [from 4th c.]
examples: My guilt thy growing virtues did defame; / My blackness blotted thy unblemish'd name.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly historical) To charge; to accuse (someone) of an offence. [from 14th c.]
examples: Rebecca is  […]  defamed of sorcery practised on the person of a noble knight.

entries.meaning: To harm or diminish the reputation of; to disparage. [from 4th c.]
